As a cyclist, a cycling fan and an Australian this photo fills me to overflowing with feelings of reverence. It was taken a couple of hundred metres from the finish line of this year’s Tour de France stage 4 and I can’t stop looking at it.

Cadel won the stage by a few centimetres by delivering a sustained attack so vicious that neither Alberto Contador, undisputedly the best climber in the world, nor Philippe Gilbert, a man who just months ago swept the Ardennes classics by destroying the rest of the field on uphill finishes exactly like this one, could come around him.

Those faces belong to two of the most dominant men, not only in cycling, but in this specific kind of finish and they are in pain. Not once this year in any of Gilbert’s destructive Ardennes wins or throughout Contador’s Giro dominance did they look like that. Cadel, an Australian, is on the front, determination contorting his face and body, forcing the best to turn themselves inside out for at most, a second place.

It is glorious.
